conclusion: The problem involves calculating the magnitude and direction of the resultant Ampere force acting on a trapezoidal wire frame in a magnetic field.
The trapezoidal frame has sides AB and CD forming an angle of 60 degrees with side AD, and ab = bc = cd = L.
The frame is connected to a power source with electromotive force E and negligible internal resistance.
There is a uniform magnetic field with magnetic induction intensity B perpendicular to the vertical plane of the frame.

premise: ab = bc = cd = L and angles are 60 degrees
ab = bc = cd = L and AD = 2L
conclusion: The total length of the wire is (3 + sqrt(3))L.

premise: Total length of wire is (3 + sqrt(3))L
conclusion: The resistance R of the wire is rho * (3 + sqrt(3))L / S.
The current I in the circuit is ES / (rho * (3 + sqrt(3))L).
The magnetic force on segment AB is BES sqrt(3) / (2 rho (3 + sqrt(3))).
The magnetic force on segment BC is BES / (2 rho (3 + sqrt(3))).
The magnetic force on segment CD is BES / (2 rho (3 + sqrt(3))).
The magnetic force on segment AD is BES sqrt(3) / (rho (3 + sqrt(3))).

premise: Forces on segments AB, BC, CD, and AD
conclusion: The magnitude of the resultant Ampere force is 5BSE / (3rho), and the direction is vertically upward.
